Time Inc. Revenue Falls; Digital Can’t Offset Print Declines
http://www.wsj.com/articles/time-inc-revenue-falls-digital-cant-offset-print-declines-1478173930 Without rehashing all the details again, moving to a bi-weekly publishing frequency really could more-or-less maintain revenue, while obtaining production savings. The new CEO is possibly a bit more honest with the future projections. An honest appraisal of TIME is also in order, and some proactive re-positioning may allow them to get ahead of a declining curve. Having said this, I'm just not so sure about the board of this firm. The board has again approved the regular quarterly dividend, which, at the current share price, yields an eye-popping 6+%. While claiming to seek to compete as a digital media firm, whose dividends are far more modest, it is continuing to pay dividends as if it were still in the monopoly news era. This firm, including TIME magazine, needs to be rationalized. For a variety of reasons the board is changing, so it is likely newer members will face the facts more candidly. There's something about this dividend that is not right. I'd look to find conflicts of interest that are keeping this rate so sticky.

I cannot see any news that suggests this is likely. If we take as a starting point that in the past new media does not totally replace old media (e.g. radio  did not completely replace newspapers, TV did not completely replace radio) and that old media after declining when new media is introduced usually drops to a new level and then plateaus rather than disappears. ebooks arrived a few years ago, grabbed market share, but now paper books and ebooks seem to be coexisting
https://www.theguardian.com/books/booksblog/2014/mar/31/paper-vs-digital-reading-debate-ebooks-tim-waterstone
at some point newspapers and magazines will reach each reach a state of balance between paper and electronic versions.  The disruption to the newspaper business has been largely due to the move of classified advertising away from newspapers, and the relatively costly expense of distribution. Weekly magazines suffer from these problems less than daily local papers. I see no reason why weekly magazines sold by the annual subscription model cannot continue after we get most of the 'news" electronically.  The daily news, online or in print is (or was) mainly reporting facts (often incorrect facts) while the news magazine is more about fitting the facts into a bigger picture of what the facts will mean mean to the readers in a longer time frame (e.g. its current affairs). 
So if I take a guess that the decline in newspapers will bottom out in the next four years or so (say 50 months) and that while lots of local news papers will stop the print edition, it will perhaps result in 25% of weekly news magazines stopping their print editions that would suggest that no more than 0.5% of news magazines will stop their print editions each month.  
http://newspaperdeathwatch.com/
Its seems that newspapers (not magazines) in the US have been closing print editions at a rate of less than 2.5% a year which would suggest that my guess of 0.5% a month is too high and that 0.2% a month is a closer estimate. If so with only 3 months to go in 2016 the likelihood of any one newspaper closing its print edition is only around 0.6%. If I assume that Time is less likely to close its print edition than average then rounded to the nearest whole number give 0%.

Rich Battista Reveals His Vision to Streamline Time Inc.
http://www.vanityfair.com/news/2016/09/rich-battista-ceo-time-inc 1) I'd be curious what an expert in discourse sentiment analysis might make of the excessive usage of the adverb "really" in this brief interview. As a non-expert, it seems to me that any speaker who goes to such lengths to emphasize how his conceptions of reality are so "real," is either unsure of those conceptions himself, or is taking special pains to convince the listener that they are "real," because he or she does not believe them to be so. 2) If we take only the new Chief Executive Officer (Mr. Battista) and the recently appointed Chief Content Officer (Mr. Murray) as representative of the mindset at Time Inc., we can safely say that the firm has no idea whatsoever about "branding." This is a qualitative insight that you won't find in the filings. Both executives have articulated the same (shared) vision for the future of Time Inc.; namely, content will be created in "topic centers" and farmed out to individual titles after-the-fact. There are efficiencies, they believe, in creating content in this fashion. This is a great example of both a) a lack of system thinking, and b) a lack of understanding branding. I forget the exact formulation, but the Ackoff system rule goes something like this: optimizing a sub-system will de-optimize the overall system. By optimizing the economic efficiency of content creation, they are de-optimizing the effectiveness of brand loyalty. In short, branding is about self-identification of the user with the object. The reason why each brand has a writer on a topic is because, presumably, each writer has a specific viewpoint and voice that resonates with the users of that brand. A generic topic-centered content creation function does not accomplish that. In the short term users may be fooled, because the user will have some lingering faith in the title (label) of the brand. But long term, the user of a brand targeted at edgy eighteen year old females just won't resonate with content written by a fifty year old male. Does the fifty year old male even have any idea of the latest slang? Where is his oh-so-familiar experience that he can use as an analogy to connect the content to the reader? (He would have no such experience.) Horrible. Time Inc. is a latent disaster, and to make matters worse, the general declining print subscription demographics will be used to explain away a strategy that will be contributing to the acceleration of that decline. Vanity Fair: When Alan Murray got the chief content officer job earlier this summer, he talked to me about melding some of the individual brand identities a bit and making the content more topic specific instead of brand specific. Do you still see that as your plan going forward? Rich Battista: Absolutely. But you can still absolutely retain the brand identity. What we’re talking about is how we leverage our content in smarter ways across the brand. Here’s a perfect example: just recently there was some news story, and I think four or five of our brands posted about it at different times, four or five different writers wrote it, and it was a pretty generic entertainment story. To me, that doesn’t seem very efficient. Why not have a news desk where everyone’s sharing. You can say, “O.K., on this one, why don’t you take this and you create that story and then everybody wins because everyone can put it on their sites at the same time when it breaks.” Just by saying the words "you can still absolutely retain the brand identity," does not make it so. Not if the top two executives in the firm don't *really* understand branding. Oh yea, skipping over reading into the very strange "we're/I" construction, "sometimes we’re going to have to make hard decisions that I don’t want to make" may be indicative of some future action as to TIME.

Time Inc.’s long, rough summer continues
http://www.medialifemagazine.com/time-inc-s-long-rough-summer-continues/ I've been curious about the logic being used to implement the editorial cuts at Time Inc., and this article suggests the inference that it may include current salary. Poor salary systems can indeed, over time, result in misalignment of salaries and productive performance, but often salaries are just an (all too) easy metric to rely upon. I've bashed Time Inc. enough already, but my final observation in this regard is that I'm getting a clear sense that they have lost touch with the branding aspect of publishing. I was particularly struck by the implication from a recent interview with Murray where he suggested that centralized content centers (e.g., health, automotive, etc.) were a direction he might be moving in. There's some sine qua non missing in such an approach that seems vital to magazine/content  branding. Do people buy a magazine for the content, or visit a website for the content, or do they view themselves as readers/participants in certain kind of content? Perhaps some of the Russian thinking on "reflexive" psychology would help Murray, et. al. No doubt there are times when people chase content down, no matter where it is, based on interest in a particular subject. There is also, however, that aspect of readership/participation in media where the consumer allows the editorial staff to lead, in a sort of serendipitous journey, because the reader/participant identifies, in some sense, with the "image" of the brand. I fear that Time Inc. has lost this understanding. Time Inc. seems to have fallen into the same trap as the auditing profession in this regard. Many markets have the characteristic of the decision-makers being different than the revenue source being different than the end-users. I feel Time Inc. has lost its way in not understanding these dynamics of their markets. They seem to believe that advertisers are their customers. They've seem to have lost sight that readers/participants are the actual decision-makers in the process.

Study: Over Two-Thirds of Americans Still Read Print Magazines
http://www.foliomag.com/2016/study-two-thirds-americans-still-read-print-magazines/ Using old (2013/2014) numbers, we might be able to ballpark a number for the cost savings available to Time Inc. if they were to change the frequency of publication of TIME from weekly to bi-weekly. In 2014 New York Magazine moved from a weekly to a bi-weekly. At that time, their subscriber base was approximately 400,000. The change in frequency resulted in annual cost savings of $3.5 million. If we assume similar cost structures (the cost savings per subscriber would be the same), a change in frequency to bi-weekly for TIME magazine (with approximately 3,000,000 subscribers) would result in $26.25 million in annual cost savings. It is interesting that at least in the case of New York magazine, by increasing the number of printed pages per issue, they were able to maintain the total number of paid advertising pages per year. 
http://www.nytimes.com/2013/12/02/business/media/long-on-cutting-edge-of-print-new-york-magazine-cuts-back.html Moody's downgrades Time Inc.

Time Inc. reported their quarterly results today. I'm not sure when the best time to announce any change in publishing frequency would be, but no such announcement was made today. (-2) Some observations/interpretations:
1) They achieved "crossover" on advertising, where increase in digital advertising revenue exceeded decrease in print revenue. Digital advertising revenue increased at an impressive 65%, whereas print revenue decreased by 13%. It is unclear if the crossover in terms of profitability has occurred.
2) "Excluding Viant acquisition, digital advertising revenue would have increased 10% year over year." Without knowing how they account for intra-company sales, it is difficult to know exactly how to interpret this statement. On the surface, however, this is a rather shocking statement. By "on the surface" I mean that the ad sales from the "digitalization" of everything Time had prior to Viant, as well all the other non-Viant digital acquisitions, increased by only 10%. This seems like they are unable to touch new customers with existing products.
3) As I read the financials, they burned through $331 million in cash for the quarter. This is an unsustainable rate (although by definition any negative cashflow is unsustainable). Recent announcements of personnel cuts will reduce editorial costs, but will not likely be enough to cover the negative cashflow by itself. Without knowing what the net estimated savings would be in terms of a TIME frequency change we are very much in the dark, but looking to production costs as the next area to cut would mean that such a change in frequency may very much be on the table. Something needs to give with the cashflow.
4) The share price for Time Inc. declined by 8.43% on heavy volume today. With the announcement of the regular dividend, this stock has a yield of 4.9%.
5) Time Inc. continues to claim that they are in the acquisitive mode, although I do not know where they would find the cash. I would not be surprised if they themselves were acquired by the likes of Verizon (although with the decline in share price today it does not seem that the market anticipates this scenario).
6) I have recently begun hearing media commentators refer to TIME not as a "news" magazine, but as a "political" magazine. Time Inc. refers to TIME as a "news weekly." "the prior comments were a journey"

I don't think they're fully appreciating the potential counter-(naive) intuitive behavior of consumers. Like where traffic accidents and injuries go up after seat belt laws are introduced (people feel safer and drive more recklessly), or where an irrecoverable loss spiral can be started by seeking to obtain revenue increases from unit price increases alone while the overall demand and infrastructure to support that demand decreases. Alternatively, they seem to be unable to move from old content through new channels to new content through all channels. Time Inc. Reorganizes Into 4 Distinct Brand Groups
http://www.adweek.com/news/press/time-inc-reorganizes-4-distinct-brand-groups-172639 Time Inc. to phase out ‘publisher’ positions
http://nypost.com/2016/07/21/time-inc-to-phase-out-publisher-positions/ What's in a job title (name)?
It's difficult to pass judgement on these changes without knowing the full history, but on the surface it seems like these job title changes are exactly the opposite of what needs to be taking place. While there is often some tension between the "content" and "business" side of media firms, the position of publisher has, for most progressive firms, been where the two meet. "Publishers" typically have full P&L responsibility for their respective titles. They are the ones who "have the vision" to see the "connection" between content and commercial success. As such, it is publishers that are making the appropriate trade-offs and undertaking the appropriate innovations to drive brand growth. By going to "editorial director" as the title for the group heads, I can only wonder where the commercial business sense, as it relates to particular properties, is to be exercised. Is it only to be exercised at the next higher-level up? That's a recipe for disaster. Is the re-titling supposed to be a signal that Time Inc. hasn't forgotten the "content" side? If so, that's a silly signal, easily seen through. In any case, they've chosen the wrong job titles if they are indeed seeking to increase commercial success of all properties across all platforms. It's actually a bit shocking.

In line with my original forecast (logic below from December), but just notching probability down now that the clock is ticking.... Time Magazine is circulated to over 3m doctors offices and waiting rooms in the US. This volume cannot easily be replaced by electronic means even if other subscriptions may continue to be cancelled by individual subscribers. 3m+ circulation is easily sufficient to make it economically viable and profitable to continue with physical circulation of the magazine. Moreover, recent ciruclation figures have been relatively stable for the past few years, suggesting that the impact of online distribution has already occurred and further erosion will be slow - possibly linked to the mortality rates of the older generation of subscribers. Moreover, Nancy Gibb - the current chief editor - was quoted in saying in 2013 that the magazine "will always exist in print". Finally, magazine publication is the core business of Time Inc and Time Magazine is the flagship product: A decision not to publish in print would be a radical departure in business strategy that is unlikely to occur first in its flagship prouct - we will likely see moves in this direction first in other publications, including Sports Illustrated etc. I might increase my probability of this event if those type of moves occur first, but for the moment the probability has to be very low (although with the caveat here that the YES is predicated on an "announcement" of the move rather than implementation of such a move, so in theory they could announce that they will stop printing in 2025 or so.)

A while back @dowser and I had an interesting conversation about this notion of "combined issues" with TIME magazine.
http://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/133177 Without rehashing everything all over again, just a few quick points:
1) Per Time Inc. 2015 10-K, TIME magazine publishes 44 issues per year. Far less, some might say, than an ordinary understanding of "weekly."
2) Per Time Inc. 2015 10-K, Time recognizes FTC regulation as an important variable effecting aspects of performance.
3) Based on limited research, I have tentatively concluded that, despite my initial assumption, there is no industry standard definition for a magazine "weekly." This, despite the fact that the term is used throughout the industry. Per the Time Inc. 2015 10-K, Time declares TIME to be a "Weekly Newsmagazine." As part of my research into the "weekly" issue, I contacted a leading magazine industry consultant. Here is her verbatim reply: "I know of no standard.  The USPS [United States Postal Service] requires publishers to describe their frequency in their mastheads and you can see just how much variety there is by reading those.  Often weekly publications come out 50 times a year with "double issues" accounting for the weeks that are missed.  (Those double issues always look like just regular issues to me, usually!). There is no official place that I know of that decides who can call themselves a weekly.  I think publishers can define their frequency any way they want to." Where I'm going with this is that I can imagine a scenario where, without any change in physical frequency whatsoever, Time Inc. would be required by the FTC to "come clean" on the arguably deceptive business practice of marketing TIME as a weekly newsmagazine yet only publishing 44 issues per year. It is also possible Time Inc. itself just decides to "come clean" on the issue. Now admittedly it's a muddy area. It would be unreasonable, I believe, to insist that publishers always adhere to some inflexible standard, because there are various reasons a publisher might wish to do special or combined issues from time-to-time to benefit the customer; and yes, even themselves once-and-awhile. The problem arises, as it so often does, when the discretion afforded to a party becomes systematically and routinely abused. Without getting into the detail of actually counting the pages per issue type (not that this is definitive), it appears that TIME is (at least) fairly close to routinely abusing that discretion. Long story short here: TIME may announce a change due to regulatory pressure or the adoption of better marketing communications with their customers. It is possible, however, that even with such a change in "policy," the respective announcement would never state that "TIME will no longer be publishing a weekly edition," because the reason they would be making such a policy announcement in the first place was because this statement was, strictly speaking, false! [Edit: One thing we can say, I think, from the industry expert, is that the masthead is one, if not "the place," where the magazine publisher announces its publishing frequency, as required by USPS regulation.]

Time Inc. anticipates more restructuring in 2016
http://www.capitalnewyork.com/article/media/2016/02/8591436/time-inc-anticipates-more-restructuring-2016 Time Inc. 2015 10-K
http://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/1591517/000159151716000039/timeinc4q2015.htm I am assuming that, at the conclusion of some detailed analysis, cost savings available from a reduction in issue frequency for TIME magazine can be shown to more than make-up for any reduction in advertising and subscription revenue (if any) that would be associated with such a change. Given that there are offsetting reductions in advertising and subscription revenues, however, and that TIME already employs a number of "combined issues," and that TIME magazine is just one property among many of the company, such savings (if any) will probably not be sufficient in and of themselves to motivate such a change. That "the bulk of our U.S. printing is consolidated under multi-year contracts with a single printer" deserves scrutiny. I must say, I enjoy total honesty. Here's a cited risk: "the ability to incur significant additional indebtedness." It's saying debt may not always be the right solution for funding a particular initiative, but since people are so willing to lend to us, we need to discipline ourselves in terms of whether and how we obtain our debt funding. While a big positive signal for management in general, it is but a tiny positive signal for frequency reduction, which would be capital generated internally via cost savings. While the 10-K makes numerous references to "reducing cost structures" (which a reduction in issue frequency would contribute to), as best as I can tell from a quick scan, there is no specific reference within the 10-K to change in publishing frequency in any fashion.

Those changes may include closing or selling some of the company's brands, or partnering with other companies on products.  "We intend to continue to evaluate our portfolio for opportunities to make internal investments, pursue strategic partnerships, close or divest titles, brands or operations where necessary, launch new titles, brands or operations and evaluate acquisition opportunities when they arise," according to the annual report. To that end, the company said that it expects to see more restructuring costs in the future, on top of the $191 million it spent in 2015 on restructuring, certain costs related to the company's office move, and building out new infrastructure. "We anticipate additional headcount and efficiency measures in the future including global sourcing of personnel, streamlining the editorial process, centralized procurement, and further elimination of duplication across brands," the 10-K read in part. But Time Inc. also highlighted the areas that it is investing in, most notably using data for better ad targeting, branded content, live events and video. So I looked at an issue of TIME.
1) FYI, it is already less than a weekly edition (that is, it is already *not* published 52 times per year). There are some number of "combined issues." The number of combined issues appears to be at the publisher's discretion; so Time Inc. may already have plans to add another combined issue or two this year as compared to last. They could achieve some cost savings by reduced paper (and printing) and mailing costs (neither of which would likely exceed those of two stand-alone issues). So, we are not forecasting the "thing," but only the "name." (-5)
2) The quality of the paper is dramatically inferior to years past. Whatever tactile appeal magazines may have once had, is lost in TIME. Photo quality suffers as well.
3) The collection of advertisers is kind of funny. It's a slice of corporate America (mostly) that you need to see for yourself to get the feel. Big pharma (many), insurance companies (many), AARP and other senior citizen groups, banks, Volkswagen (curious), US Ad Council, and Mexican vacations. Plus an Amazon and another ad that likely reflects some traded advertising as part of their recent strategic relationships. In general, I saw the advertisers as representing very large firms with massive advertising budgets that are probably not required to justify their advertising spend in terms of effectiveness. It's image (versus product) advertising dollars that are farmed through agencies and the like. It would be just that collection of advertisers if there was some group that wanted to support a mainstream narrative of reality. These are not the kind of advertisers that will likely go away if there is a (further) frequency change; but perhaps more importantly, they are so locked in that they can be milked with the current frequency and rate hikes quite a bit longer. [Edit#1: There probably is some magazine industry convention that dictates when some number of pre-planned "combined issues" knocks one out of the "weekly" category. Or, there may not be. Based on the number of combined issues I saw, I'm guessing they only publish 45 or so issues (mailings) per year at present.] [Edit#2: I'm reducing my forecast because there are less cost savings readily available via reduction in frequency than I had initially assumed. I'm not taking it too much lower at present because having already picked up the "low hanging fruit" of combined issues, it is likely any further reduction in frequency will force them to declare themselves ineligible for the "weekly" category. How the industry determines a "weekly" is unknown to me, but knowable, and important.]

The long-term trend among print publications is towards creating digital-only properties, but it's very difficult to know when publishers will make make that switch, and also, what factors will drive their decision to do so. It's a rational assumption that publishers make the decision based on a few factors: 1) demographic trends in their consumer base, 2) relatedly, preferences of their user base in how they want to consume news media, and 3) ability to maximize operating margins, as a function of revenue (from consumer subscriptions + advertising) relative to costs. My sense is that Time has a large and aging consumer demographic (i.e. the majority of their paid home subscribers are older than 35) and many paid enterprise subscribers like dentist offices, law firms, universities, and libraries want to make print copies of publications available to visitors. Based on these assumptions, I think that Time still gets a significant proportion of its subscriber revenue from print subscribers, and wouldn't want to risk shrinking its paid subscriber base by forcing subscribers to consume Time exclusively in a digital format anytime soon. Also, assuming the New York Times is a good proxy for Time in terms of core subscriber audience, it's notable that the NYT decided to expand aggressively into digital subscriptions a few years ago while still maintaining a daily print version of the paper. Of course, the other plausible reason TIME would no longer publish a weekly print edition is existential: suppose it just can't continue to make money as a news magazine, or the costs of publishing weekly are unsustainable financially? So, to save costs, TIME's editorial board may continue the print publication, but publish on a monthly basis instead of a weekly basis. :) Looking at the performance of Time's parent company, Time, Inc., on the NYSE in the last year, there's been a pretty steady-rate decline totaling 40% in valuation. This suggests that some of its media properties are not faring well financially, and is likely increasing shareholder pressure to scale back or shut down losing properties while investing more in profitable ones. In the event that this rate of decline in valuation continues--or accelerates--I would expect more drastic decisions  possibly by new executive leadership re: frequency of publishing print version of Time magazine.

Time Magazine is circulated to over 3m doctors offices and waiting rooms in the US. This volume cannot easily be replaced by electronic means even if other subscriptions may continue to be cancelled by individual subscribers. 3m+ circulation is easily sufficient to make it economically viable and profitable to continue with physical circulation of the magazine. Moreover, recent ciruclation figures have been relatively stable for the past few years, suggesting that the impact of online distribution has already occurred and further erosion will be slow - possibly linked to the mortality rates of the older generation of subscribers. Moreover, Nancy Gibb - the current chief editor - was quoted in saying in 2013 that the magazine "will always exist in print".  Finally, magazine publication is the core business of Time Inc and Time Magazine is the flagship product:  A decision not to publish in print would be a radical departure in business strategy that is unlikely to occur first in its flagship prouct - we will likely see moves in this direction first in other publications, including Sports Illustrated etc.  I might increase my probability of this event if those type of moves occur first, but for the moment the probability has to be very low (although with the caveat here that the YES is predicated on an "announcement" of the move rather than implementation of such a move, so in theory they could announce that they will stop printing in 2025 or so.
